conclusion: The dipole consists of two charges +q and -q separated by a distance d.
The dipole is initially aligned along the X-axis with an angular velocity ω0.
The magnetic field B is perpendicular to the XY-plane, pointing out of the plane (along the Z-axis).

premise: Each charge experiences a Lorentz force due to the magnetic field: F = q(v × B) where v is the velocity of the charge.
conclusion: Since the dipole is rotating, the charges have velocities perpendicular to the rod, leading to forces that create a torque.

premise: The torque τ on the dipole due to the magnetic field is given by: τ = p × B where p = qd is the dipole moment.
conclusion: For the dipole aligned along the X-axis, τ = qdB j. This torque tends to rotate the dipole about the Y-axis.
The angular momentum L of the dipole about its center of mass is: L = Iω0 k where I = (1/12)md^2 is the moment of inertia of the dipole.
The initial kinetic energy is: K = (1/2)Iω0^2.

premise: To reverse orientation, the dipole must overcome the potential energy associated with the magnetic field.
conclusion: The potential energy U of the dipole in the magnetic field is: U = -p · B = -qdBcosθ where θ is the angle between p and B.
The initial kinetic energy must be at least equal to the potential energy at θ = 180°: (1/2)Iω0^2 ≥ qdB.
The minimal angular velocity ωmin necessary for the dipole to reverse its orientation is: ωmin = sqrt((24qB)/(md)).
